# Frontend Crash Course!
------

Hello, [Wrold](https://medium.com/@the_taqquikarim/console-log-hello-wrold-3e3abeb44396)! Welcome!

In this class, we will cover some of the basics of web development. This will include discussion on stuff like HTML, CSS and deployment to the web.

### Objectives

* write HTML from scratch
* use CSS to style our HTML
* deploy our page to the internet
* understand bootstrap + other frontend frameworks

guts-of-a-http-request.content:
## Guts of an HTML Request
---

### Question
What happens when you type in [http://www.google.com](http://www.google.com) into the web browser?

### Answer
A **lot** of background tasks get executed.

1. Browser has no idea what `google` is. It begins by looking up your web url in something called the **DNS**: the *Domain Name System*.
2. The DNS maps to a specific **IP address**, a collection of numbers that works much like your phone number works.
3. The browser now knows *where* to send a **HTTP request**. It does this.
4. After a little while, a **response** comes back to the request sent. 
5. The browser parses this response and figures out what to do with this data (ie: should I draw it in the window? does this need to be download? Streamed? etc)
6. **???**
7. Profit

### Question

Where does this response comes from?

### Answer 

A little ol' thing called a **server**.

Servers are basically computers that have __one__ specific job: listen for requests from computers like yours. 

Based on the request, the server determines what to do: 
* should it respond at all? 
* Should it send back an image? 
* A video? 
* A webpage? 
* Etc.

### Question

Why does it matter even? Why do __we__, aspiring web developers, even care what the server does?

### Answer

The way a server stores data and responds to requests gives us valuable insight into how we can build websites of our own...in our own machines.

taking-a-peek-inside-a-server.content:
## Looking into the abyss...err, server 
---

At the end of the day, a server is **just a computer**...kinda like yours, only on steroids.

More importantly, a website is essentially **just a folder structure that contains a very specific set of files**.

Kinda like this:

```html
myAwesomeFirstSite (folder)
    assets (folder)
        backgroundImage.jpg
         ...
         myDashingMug.png
     styles (folder)
         reset.css
         ...
         main.css
     javsacript (folder)
         main.js
     index.html
     about.html
     contact.html
```

A few notes for you:

1. **myAwesomeFirstSite** is the folder that will contain all the other folders that you need for your site to work
2. note that our filenames and folder names have **NO spaces or any other funky business**. This is important! Just letters and numbers and underscores allowed! (Dashes are ok too but I recommend staying away from them).
3. Inside our **myAwesomeFirstSite** folder, we have three other folders
 1. **assets**: all website images should go here
 2. **styles**: all your CSS files should go here
 3. **javascript**: all your js files should go here


### Question

How do we test our websites?

# Bro: do you even HTML? --- Your typical HTML file will look like this: ```html My First Awesome Site ``` **``** This tag tells the browser to read our HTML content as HTML5, the latest and greatest revision of the HTML spec. We MUST include it as the first thing on our .html files. I usually type it as all lower case, but it's common practice to also type as: **``** This is the root tag. Basically, all other tags in your html file must live inside this tag. Note how on the bottom of the code snippet, we have a "". This is called closing a tag and we must close all tags that we open (with the exception of a few). If we do not do this, our HTML markup becomes invalid. **``** This section contains content that does not show the user things. Typically, we would expect to see things such as the page title, external links, and SEO tags here. **``** All the magic happens here.
